node.title: Kung Pao Chicken

seo.metaDesc: Dried chiles sizzled in oil add just enough heat to the savory-sweet Sichuan classic gong bao ji ding, or kung pao chicken.
seo.opengraphDescription: Dried chiles sizzled in oil add just enough heat to the savory-sweet Sichuan classic gong bao ji ding, or kung pao chicken.
seo.title: Kung Pao Chicken Recipe (Gong Bao Ji Ding) | Saveur

blocks.name: core/paragraph
blocks.attributesJSON: {"content":"The <a href=\"https:\/\/www.saveur.com\/best-sichuan-recipes\/\">Sichuan<\/a> dish gong bao ji ding\u2014often better known by its Americanized name kung pao chicken\u2014is a dainty assemblage of small, plump chicken morsels, peanuts, and scallions, with just enough chiles to give it a kick. This recipe is adapted from China Club, a private club in Beijing that serves a thrilling menu of classic Chinese dishes: spicy Sichuan, delicate Cantonese, and rich Shanghainese, with refined versions of Beijing specialties as well.","dropCap":false,"anchor":""}
blocks.originalContent: The Sichuan dish gong bao ji dingâoften better known by its Americanized name kung pao chickenâis a dainty assemblage of small, plump chicken morsels, peanuts, and scallions, with just enough chiles to give it a kick. This recipe is adapted from China Club, a private club in Beijing that serves a thrilling menu of classic Chinese dishes: spicy Sichuan, delicate Cantonese, and rich Shanghainese, with refined versions of Beijing specialties as well.

recipe.author: SAVEUR Editors
recipe.description: The Sichuan dish gong bao ji dingâoften better known by its Americanized name kung pao chickenâis a dainty assemblage of small, plump chicken morsels, peanuts, and scallions, with just enough chiles to give it a kick. This recipe is adapted from China Club, a private club in Beijing that serves a thrilling menu of classic Chinese dishes: spicy Sichuan, delicate Cantonese, and rich Shanghainese, with refined versions of Beijing specialties as well.

items.ingredient: 1 lb. boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cubed
4 tsp. Chinkiang (black) vinegar (or substitute balsamic vinegar)
12 small dried red chiles, stemmed, halved crosswise, and seeded
5 scallions, white part only, thickly sliced crosswise
One Â½-in. piece fresh ginger, peeled and finely chopped
Â½ cup shelled, skinless raw peanuts

instructions.text: In a medium bowl, stir together 1 tablespoon of the soy sauce and the cornstarch. Add the chicken, toss well, and set aside to marinate for 30 minutes.
Meanwhile, in a separate medium bowl, stir together the Shaoxing wine, stock, sugar, sesame oil, vinegar, dark soy sauce, and the remaining soy sauce.
instructions.name: instruction 1

instructions.text: To a large wok or nonstick skillet over high heat, add the oil. When itâs just beginning to smoke, add the chiles, half the scallions, the garlic, ginger, and the marinated chicken, and stir-fry until the chicken is golden, 3â5 minutes. Add the soy sauce mixture and continue stir-frying until the sauce thickens, about 2 minutes more.
Stir in the peanuts, garnish with the remaining scallions, and serve immediately.

recipe.name: Kung Pao Chicken
